Jenelyn D. A. is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a slippers retailing business in the Philippines. Jenelyn has been in this business for 12 years. She earns additional income from RTW (Ready-To-Wear) clothing.

She is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to buy more stock of slippers to sell in her stall.

Jenelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy more stocksof slippers to sell in her stall.

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores E. is 48 years old and married with six children.

Dolores work hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines. She has been running the sari-sari store for five years and also earns an income from rice retailing.

She has requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF to buy items like sardines, groceries, etc., to sell in her sari-sari store.

Dolores has borrowed and repaid 11 loans from NWTF before this loan. 

She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy items to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Flordiliza

texts.en:
Flordiliza Lodivico is 42 years old and has a retail shop where she sells different products. Flordiliza has had this business for one year. She has five school-aged children and she is married.

Flordiliza is requesting a loan of 10,000 to purchase additional products to sell like spices and soft drinks. Each month, Flordiliza earns about PHP 5,000 doing this type of work.

In the future, Flordiliza hopes to expand her business to support the daily needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like spices and soft drinks

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline Santiago is 53 years old and married. She is engaged in the retail sector managing a general store. She offers different products like frozen foods. She has been in the business for almost six years now and she usually earns 4,000 PHP a month.

To further improve her business, Evangeline is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP to purchase products such as hot dogs and patties to sell. 

Evangeline Santiago dreams of enlarging her general store so that she can further improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase products such as hot dogs and patties to sell

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita A. is now 56 years old and married with six adult-aged children. Rosita is a farmer working in the Philippines and earns PHP 8,000 per month. 

Rosita is asking for a loan of PHP 12,000 to purchase corn seeds and pay for services to plant corn. She grows corn and has been doing this for 25 years.

In the future, Rosita hopes to produce a large quantity of corn and a make a higher income to supplement their daily basic needs and save for the future.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and to pay for services to plant the corn

loans.name: Marie Gay Rose

texts.en:
Marie Gay Rose Reyes is married and 43 years old. She has a retail shop where she sells different products. She has been managing this business for almost six years now and generates an income per month of 3,500 PHP. She utilizes her income for their daily expenditures.

Marie Gay Rose Reyes is requesting a loan of 18,000 to purchase stock of products such as soft drinks, toothpaste and condiments.

In the future, Marie Gay Rose Reyes hopes that her business will expand in order to earn a bigger income.

loans.use: to purchase soft drinks, toothpaste and condiments

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina D. is now 38 years old and married with three school-aged children. Josefina is a farmer working in the Philippines. She earns PHP 13,000 per month. 

Josefina is asking for a loan of PHP 25,000 to purchase fertilizers and pesticides. She grows corn on her plantation and has been doing this for almost eight years.

In the future, Josefina hopes to produce a high quantity of corn and earn a higher income to finance the education of their children. She believes that with her strong determination, she hopes that they can improve their living conditions andt that their children will have a brighter future.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en:
With the desire to further develop her general store, Teodora Layco decided to borrow a loan from ASKI and KIVA lenders for 21, 000 PHP. She will use the looan to buy commodities like canned goods, soft drinks, detergent soap and condiments.


Teodora Layco is married and 49 years old. In the future, Teodora aims to retail rice in her store to generate more income.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, soft drinks, detergent soap and condiments.

loans.name: Ramzana's Group

texts.en:
Ramzana is a housewife who stays at home and does her household responsibilities. Her husband sells milk from his shop, which is located in the market. Ramzana is 33 years old and a mother of three children. Two of them are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. Ramzana wants to send her younger daughter to school. She is 10 years old, but Ramzana doesn’t have enough financial resources. 

She wants to help her husband improve his business so she has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah. With the loan, her husband will purchase milk in larger quantity, which will help him increase his sales and improve his income. He has been operating this business for the past 10 years and it is going reasonably well for him. Ramzana hopes that after the loan, it will further improve and she will be able to send her younger daughter to school. 

She lives in a city called Arifwala, which is located in Punjab, Pakistan and known for its dairy industry. Her house contains three rooms and she moved here 10 years ago.

loans.use: To buy milk to sell

loans.name: Miến's Group

texts.en:
Miến(20201070010) is a 36-year-old woman living in the town of Huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Miến is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Trung Bạn - nhóm 08 (8).

Miến is married and has four school-aged children.  To make a living, Miến owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale.  Miến has been engaged in this business for over eight years and earns approximately 3,400,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2008, Miến joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Miến has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,392,000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 8,288,000 VND which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies.  This will be the 4th loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA.  Miến plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1. Lợi is a 29-year-old woman who is requesting a 8,288,000 VND loan to support her business  manufacturing tables, chairs, and cabinets.


2. Hoa is a 31-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,496,000 VND loan to support her business manufacturing beds and wardrobes.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Miến N. Thị (20201070010) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Miến là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 3 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Trung Bạn - nhóm 08 (8).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi heo để bán.  Miến thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 8 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Miến kiếm được khoảng 3.400.000 VND.  Vào 2008, Miến đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Miến đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 7.392.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.288.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  N. Thị Lợi (0) là 29 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 8.288.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh sản xuất hàng nội thất, bàn, ghế, tủ.


2.  N. Thị Hoa (0) là 31 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.496.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh sản xuất hàng nội thất, giường, tủ.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
To earn an income to support her family needs, Janet Cabrera has a general store where she offers different products needed by her co-villagers. With these activities, Janet usually generates 4,000 PHP, which she utilizes as rolling capital for the business and for financing her family's daily food intake.

Currently, Janet is requesting a loan of 17,000 PHP to buy products to sell such as biscuits, canned goods, coffee, sugar and soap. Janet hopes that her business will continuously prosper.

loans.use: to buy products to sell such as biscuits, canned goods, coffee, sugar and soap

loans.name: Oltinoi's Group

texts.en:
Oltinoi J., 37 and divorced, is the treasurer of this group. She takes care of two daughters, one 14 years of age and in school, and one under seven who is not yet attending school.

Three years ago, with an initial investment of 5000 soms, Oltinoi started selling a variety of women’s jackets, skirts and dresses in the market and now earns 8000 soms per month. With the business profits, Oltinoi has improved her family's living conditions and paid for her daughter's school tuition. She has applied for this loan in order to purchase more clothes to sell. In the future Oltinoi plans to expand her business and dreams of opening her own store.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Iona

texts.en:
Iona, who is married, sells clothing at an open market in the town of Novomoskovsk. Good location and affordable prices attract many customers, earning her a net monthly profit of 6,000 Grivnas. Iona has been in the clothing sales business for 11 years but took a break a few years ago to care for her baby daughter. When her daughter turned two years old, Iona decided to return to her business.

Iona is requesting a loan of 20,000 Grivnas to purchase swimming shorts and socks for the coming summer season. This business is the only source of income for Iona’s family.

loans.use: to purchase swimming shorts and socks to sell.

loans.name: Delmar

texts.en:
Delmar is a hardworking entrepreneur living in the Philippines. He is 23 years old and married with one infant child. Delmar's spouse devotes herself full time to nursing their child.

He has been in the motorcycle transport services business for five years. Each month, Delmar earns approximately PHP 5,000. He is asking for a loan of PHP 18,000. He plans to use this loan to repair the trouble he has with an existing vehicle to ensure the safety of the passengers and to purchase accessories for better services.  

Delmar has been a client of ASKI for three years. In the future, he would like to diversify his business and earn additional money to save for future emergencies.

loans.use: to repair his existing vehicle and purchase other accessories

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is widowed. She owns a retail business selling various agricultural products like seeds, fertilizers, bug killers, etc. Tatyana has a large assortment of products, affordable prices and a good reputation at the market. She has many repeat clients who buy items from her to use on their gardens.

Tatyana has been in this business for 17 years. The business is seasonal, with items selling mostly in spring and summer. In this particular area, many people grow a lot of vegetables, so Tatyana's goods are in demand. 

Tatyana is requesting a loan of 20,000 Grivnas to purchase seeds in bulk for planting the second crop. She hopes to develop her business further and have more clients who would use her services.

(on the picture Tatyana is with her worker)

loans.use: to purchase seeds in bulk for planting the second crop

loans.name: Nanjiddash

texts.en:
Mr. Nanjiddash is a 31 year-old truck driver. He lives with his wife and 2 children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His son attends a school and his daughter goes to kindergarten. His wife is unemployed at the moment, and she looks after the kids. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.

Nanjiddash owns a small truck and uses it for his delivery business, which is family’s only source of income. He has been running this business for 6 years and he works 6 days a week from 8:00 till 21:00. He used to transport coal from the train station to households, but now he has changed the profile and he delivers his clients' goods and products from warehouses to a market site. He says its more profitable than carrying coal. He needs to remodel his truck to accommodate it for delivery of goods. The loan will be used to buy spare parts such as new tires, engine parts, and a new loader and to properly service his truck.

loans.use: to buy spare parts such as new tires, engine parts, new loader, and to properly service his truck.

loans.name: Kuljan's Group

texts.en:
Kuljan S. is the leader of this group. She is 52 and unfortunately, she is a widow. She brings up two sons and a daughter. The daughter is married and lives separately with her family. The first son works in construction and the second studies at school. Four years ago, with the initial investment of 5000 soms, Kuljan opened a kiosk and started to sell drinks, ice cream and cigarettes. In this way, she earns 6000 soms per month.  With money received from the loan, she wants to build a shed near the kiosk and purchase more goods for sale. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to build a shed near the kiosk

loans.name: Farzana's Group

texts.en:
Farzana lives in the city of Arifwala, which is located in Pakistan and is known for its agricultural industry. She has been living there in a two-room brick house for the past 15 years. She is 33 years old, married to M. S. and has six children. Three of them are studying and the rest stay at home. 

Farzana is a housewife. She spends most of her time staying at home and carrying out her household responsibilities. She makes the utmost effort to provide comfort to her family by fulfilling their needs. Her husband owns a small piece of land and grows different seasonal crops on it to fulfill the basic needs of his family. He is a very hardworking person and does his work with great dedication. 

Farzana has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her husband who will buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides to get better output from his land. He has been operating this business for 10 years and Farzana hopes that an investment will bring more profits to him.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides for an agricultural business.

loans.name: Davaasuren

texts.en:
Mrs. Davaasuren C. is a 51 year-old widow. She has 2 children who are married and live with their families. Her husband passed away last year from cancer.  Davaasuren lives on her own in her house in Darkhan, the second largest city of Mongolia. She works in “Solongo”, a small food factory, as a manager. The factory makes different types of jams and purees from fruits.  

Each year she does some renovations to her house. Last year she managed to replace all the windows of the house. Now she is planning to do some renovations to the interior of the house. The loan will be used to replace ceiling and wall papers and to do some interior renovation to the house.

loans.use: to replace hanging ceiling and wall paper and do some interior renovation to the house.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta M. is from the village of Looc, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old. Violeta is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Violeta owns & operates a business selling a variety of goods to the local community. Violeta has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Violeta joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Violeta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Violeta is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase rice and corn grits for sale. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Violeta from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase rice and corn grits for sale

loans.name: Baktykan's Group

texts.en:
Baktykan U. is the treasurer of this group. She is 42 years old, married, and has two adult children. Five months ago with the initial investment of 30,000 soms, Baktykan opened a pavilion and started to sell groceries. She earns 20,800 soms per month. With money from the loan, she wants to purchase more drinks, foodstuffs, macaroni. etc. In the future Baktykan hopes to purchase a three-room flat. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase drinks and foodstuff

loans.name: Chuluunbaatar

texts.en: Chuluunbaatar G. is 32 years old, married, and has two children, both of whom attend school. They live in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife works at a gas station as a petrol dispenser. Chuluunbaatar works at a leather and hide processing factory as a machine operator. He has been working there for 11 years. His family owns a small plot of land and a house. Chuluunbaatar likes gardening and farming. His garden has lots of fruit trees. He is planning to raise a pigs using some free space in his backyard. Currently he is building a barn for pigs. He is requesting a loan, which he will  use to buy wood planks to complete the barn and to buy 10 piglets to raise.

loans.use: To purchase wood planks to complete a barn for pigs and to buy 10 piglets to raise.

loans.name: Elmira's Group

texts.en:
Elmira S. is the leader of this group. She is 46, widowed, and has four children, two of whom attend school and two of whom work.  In order to earn money to meet the family's needs, Elmira sells five liters of milk every day and earns 2,100 soms per month. Elmira also cultivates agricultural products and sells part of the harvest to earn additional money. With the money received from the loan, she wants to purchase fuel and fertilizers for field work. In the future Elmira wants to see her children get married. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fuel and fertilizers

loans.name: Irshaad

texts.en: Irshaad lives in Kasur, which is known for its tanneries industry. She has been living in the area of Azhar colony in a two-room brick house with her family. She has given birth to three sons. Her eldest son is 20 years old and makes chikhs (an Urdu language word). Chikhs are used for shelter against heat and sunshine and are made from bamboos. Her second son is an embroidery expert while the youngest one is 9 years old and studying in the third class. Irshaad is a widow and lost her husband a few years ago. It was a very difficult time for her, but she never lost heart and raised her children. Now her children are earning well for her. She is a very caring mother and does her household tasks at home. Irshaad has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, because her eldest son wants to improve his chikhs making business. With this loan, he will buy bamboos and ropes in larger quantity which will help him fulfill clients' orders on time and earn better profits. He has been operating this business for 10 years and Irshaad is confident that his business will further expand after making an investment in it. Irshaad is a new loan applicant; this is her first loan application to Asasah. She is hopeful that it will help her son improve his business.

loans.use: to buy bamboos and ropes for a business making chikhs (used for shelter against heat and sunshine).

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana C. lives in the village of Magsaysay, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old, married and has two school-aged children. For the last five years she has made a living by running a store where she buys and sells coconuts. She earns about 2,800 PHP a month.

In 2009, Susana joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid three previous loans and is applying for a new one, for 15,000 PHP, to buy more items to sell to her customers. She pans to use the additional revenue she earns as a result of this loan to continue improving her business. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and women and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy coconuts to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina D. C. lives in the village of Campo 4, Ramon Magsaysay, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 22 years old, married and has one child, an infant. For the last seven years, she has made a living by growing rice and earns about 10,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2009, Rosalina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid five previous loans from GDMPC and is applying for a new one, for 50,000 PHP, to buy fertilizer for her farm. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to improve her family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and women and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for a rice farm.

location.town: Campo 4, Ramon MAgsaysay Zamboanga Del Sur

loans.name: Zarina

texts.en:
Zarina lives in a small city of Punjab, Pakistan, called Kasur. It is famous for its tanneries industry. She has been living in a two-room brick house in the area of Azhar colony with her family for the past many years. She is more than 50 years of age and does embroidery to help bear the financial burden of her family. Her son is also involved with her in this business. Both of them earn good income and their family is able to survive financially by their combined efforts. 

Zarina is very good at her work and receives regular orders from her neighboring customers. She has been doing this business for 10 years and has a good name in her region for the good quality of her work. She has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for the further expansion of her business. With this loan, she will buy embroidery materials such as beads, colored thread and cloth in bulk quantity that will help her and her son fulfill larger orders on time and make more profits. She has a lot of confidence in herself, and is hopeful that an investment will bring more profits to her. 

Zarina is a new loan user and this is her first loan application to Asasah. She is confident about her family’s better financial future.

loans.use: to buy embroidery material for an embroidery business.

loans.name: Monina

texts.en:
Monina P. lives in the village of Poblacion Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 51 years old, married and has four grown children. For the last 33 years, she has made a living by selling clothing to people in her community. She earns about 15,300 PHP a month from her work.

In 2007, Monina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid nine previous loans from GDMPC and is applying for a new one, for 30,000 PHP, to buy additional items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to improve her family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and women and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Jason

texts.en:
Jason M. is a farmer in Nkubu producing maize, beans, wheat, potatoes, and milk.  He has been a farmer for the last 15 years. He is married and has three adult children. He earns additional income from a cereals business he runs in the local market.

Jason is requesting a loan for 60,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase seeds and expand his farm acreage for maize, beans, and wheat.This is Jason's second loan with Juhudi Kilimo . He says this will go well with his cereals business as he will be selling his own produce rather than sourcing from other farmers. This, in turn, will give him better margins for the cereals business and enable him to adequately provide for his family. He is focusing on having buying a vehicle to supply his cereals beyond the local market. Jason mentions poor market prices and pests as the main challenges to his business. He remains glad Juhudi Kilimo provides small farmers with loans.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and expand his farm acreage

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe M. is from the village of Lantungan, Aurora Zamboanga del sur. She is 55 years old, married, and has five adult children. To make a living, Fe  raisies crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. Fe has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Fe joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fe has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC, which was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Fe is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be Fe's second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has  branches  offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherpeople, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Rosalita

texts.en:
Rosalita L. is from the village of Kauswagan, Aurora zamboanga del sur. She is 53, married, and has two adult children. Rosalita has had a rice farm for over eight years and earns approximately 8000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2007, Rosalita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from GDMPC, which was for 10,000 PHP and was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. 

This loan will be her fifth from GDMPC. Rosalita is requesting 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC: 

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy iron sheet and to pay for labour

loans.name: Lelia

texts.en:
Lelia V. is from the village of Alang-Alang, Aurora zamboanga del sur. She is 58, married, and has four adult children. Lelia has a general store that sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste. Lelia has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 6000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2011, Lelia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Lelia is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lelia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC: 

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 38, married, and runs a green grocery. She has been in this business for five years. Mary, a mother of three, works hard in her business so that she can provide for her family. She says that since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has become financially stable. In the future, she hopes to have a well-established business. She needs 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy bananas, oranges and vegetables.

loans.use: To buy bananas, oranges and vegetables

loans.name: Anvarjon

texts.en:
Anvarjon is married and the young father of one son. He is a singer, he has a band and plays at traditional weddings and other events in his region. His group is very popular in his region and he has many orders for different events. 

Each performance depends on different occasions and makes good memories. That’s why he tries to make his clients happy  in order to give them good memories. For this purpose he requested a loan of 4700 Somoni to purchase a a keyboard. 

Besides this business he is running an animal husbandry business and processing dry fruits at home. This loan will be the fourth loan for Anvarjon from Imon International and he has a good credit history.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy a musical instrument

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en:
Naseem lives in a small city of Punjab, Pakistan called Kasur. it is known for its leather industry. She has been living there in a 2-room brick house with her family in the area of Azher colony for many years. 

She is a housewife and prefers staying at home doing household work. She is an active lady and also supports her husband in his business in her spare time. Her husband is a cobbler by profession and makes shoes on order. This is his family business because his three sons and a daughter are also attached to the same business. They receive orders from different shoe-manufacturing factories and shoes selling shops and fulfil them on time to earn profit. Collectively they are able to support their household very well. 

Naseem has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her husband’s business. Through the loan, her husband will buy leather, nails, shoe-polisher and glue, etc. in bulk to be able to fulfill orders on time and make larger profits. 

Her husband has been involved in this business for the past seven years and Naseem is very confident that an investment will help him make more profits and sales. 

She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application to Asasah.

loans.use: To buy leather, nails, shoe-polisher & glue for shoe making business

loans.name: Livingstone

texts.en:
Livingstone is 30 years old. He is married and has two children. He has been operating a butcher shop for ten years. Besides this, he also does farming.  

With income from his business, Livingstone is able to provide for his family including educating his two children. His dreams and aspirations are to expand his business and to open other outlets of his business. He has requested for a loan of 20,000 KES to buy meat and a scale.

loans.use: To buy meat and a scale.

loans.name: Amos

texts.en:
Amos is a resident and farmer in Nkubu area of Central Kenya. He has been in farming for 5 years and employs one farmhand. He is single. His farm produces bananas, milk, vegetables and beans. He earns additional income from his emloyment as a driver.

Amos has made a second loan request with Juhudi Kilimo, amounting to 80,000 KES. This will enable him to cultivate a bigger and better banana plantation for commercial purposes. He adds that he wants to continue doing bigger and bigger farms. This will enable him to gain on economies of scale and he believes that he will be able to uplift his standard of living and make his asset base stronger. He specifies that the Juhudi loan allowed him to acquire his own piece of land and he would like to continue doing the same.

Amos also points out that fluctuating market prices and pests are the greatest threat to their businesses.

loans.use: To pay for more cultivation commercial banana plantation

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy more fish to sell. Vivian has been in this business for 4 years. She earns additional income from food vending.

Vivian has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money in order to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Rebelita

texts.en:
Rebelita G. is now 48 years old and married with three school-aged children. Rebelita is a farmer working in the Philippines who earns approximately PHP 8,000 per month. 

Rebelita is asking for a loan of PHP 18,000 to purchase fertilizers and pesticides. Rebelita has been growing corn for almost 15 years.

In the future, Rebelita hopes to have a plentiful harvest and earn a higher income. She hopes that someday she can start another kind of business and she dreams that their children will have a brighter future.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Aloyce

texts.en:
Aloyce is a hardworking man. He does welding to earn his living. He has been in the business for two years. He is also employed.  

Aloyce joined Faulu Kenya because he wanted to access business loans easily. Through Faulu Kenya, he has learned how to save his money. In five years, he hopes to grow his clientele. He has requested for 15,000 KES to buy a welding machine.

loans.use: To buy a welding machine.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita is 57 years old. She is married and has 5 children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Lolita has a food vending business in the Philippines. Lolita requested a PHP 19,500 loan amount through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business. Lolita has been in this business for 16 years. In the future, Lolita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva C. is 44 years old and married with 4 children.

Eva works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari sari store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 17000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like noodles, groceries, etc in her sari-sari store.

Eva has borrowed and repaid 11 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari sari store for 10 years and also earns an income from the retail sale of rice and charcoal.

Eva aspires to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: To purchase additional items to sell

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina Leano is a 61-year-old woman living in Magsaysay, Naguilan, Ilagan, Isabela. She is widowed and has six adult children.

Josefina has been in the business of selling a variety of medicine in her community for five years. She plans to use this loan to purchase additional medicine to sell.

In the future, Josefina would like to expand her business to support the needs of her children.

loans.use: to purchase additional medicine to sell

loans.name: George

texts.en: George is 78 years old and hardworking.  He is a married man with eight children.   He started a laundry business after retiring as a church pastor four years ago.  He joined a group in Faulu Kenya so that he would easily access loans because the members of the group guarantee each others loans.  George hopes to grow his business and open other branches and employ people.   He has requested a loan for 30, 000 Kes to rent a business premise and to buy an iron box.

loans.use: To rent a business premise and buy an iron box.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith  is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 29500 through NWTF to purchase more fish to sell.

Judith has been in this business for 25 years. Judith earns additional income from operating a general store.

Judith has been sustained in her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF. She hopes to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Hanzel

texts.en:
Hanzel H. is 35 years old and married but has no children yet. Hanzel is a hog raiser working in the Philippines and earns approximately PHP 8,000 per month. 

Hanzel is asking for a loan of PHP 20,000 to purchase livestock feed and vitamins. Hanzel has been raising hogs for almost six years.

In the future, Hanzel hopes to improve the kind of business he manages and start another kind of business in order to give his family a better future.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed and vitamins

location.town: Mabasa Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 54 years old and married with 5 children.

Elizabeth works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 19,500 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell in her sari-sari store.

Elizabeth has borrowed and repaid 14 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 15 years and also earns an income from farming rice.

Elizabeth aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell in her sari-sari store

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes is 49 years old, married and has 4 children, two of whom are in school.

Mercedes is in the pig fattening business in the Philippines. Mercedes has requested a PHP 20000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Mercedes has been pig fattening for 6 years now, and has borrowed  and repaid 17 loans in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Mercedes would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: To buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en: Imelda is a married mother of two children who works hard to support her family. She has a furniture making business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from her sari-sari (variety) store. Imelda is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy raw materials for her furniture-making business. She has kept her business going through her past six loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for her furniture making business

loans.name: Nympha

texts.en: Nympha, 38, is a married woman with three children in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur with a clothing sales business in the Philippines. Nympha requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stocks of ready-to-wear clothing to sell. She has been in this business for 5 years. In the future, Nympha would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more ready-to-wear clothing to sell

loans.name: George

texts.en: George is 35 years old and the father of two. He sells fish to earn a living for his family. He has operated the business for 17 years and so far has employed two people to assist him in his tasks. Through Faulu Kenya, he has improved his business with his previous loans. He hopes to have a well-established business in the future. He needs 50,000 Kes to add stock of fish.

loans.name: Estela

Estela has been in this business for 6 years and also earns additional income selling dried fish. She has kept her business going through her own efforts and the help of loans from NWTF. loans.name: Hesle

texts.en: Hesle is 43 years old and married with one child. She works hard to provide for her family by running a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF to buy assorted goods for her store. Hesle has borrowed and repaid 17 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running her store for two years and also earns income from raising goats. Hesle aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.name: Yolanda

Yolanda is now 53 years old and married with five adult-aged children. Yolanda is a duck raiser working in the Philippines and earns approximately PHP 4,000 per month. 

Yolanda is asking for a loan of PHP 8,000 to purchase ducks bearing eggs and feed for their maintenance. Yolanda has been raising ducks for almost 15 years.

In the future, Yolanda hopes to strengthen this kind of business as one source of their income in order to improve their living status and satisfy their daily basic needs.

loans.name: Elvie

Elvie is 42 years old. She is married and has nine children.

Elvie works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell in her sari-sari store.

Elvie has borrowed and paid back 14 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 9 years and also earns an income from food vending.

Elvie aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.name: Kambuga Bakyara Kwekamba Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
Mary S. is the leader of Kambuga Bakyara kwekamba group in Kihihi. She is 52 years old and married. Her 3 children all go to school. Mary has been in the business of selling produce, mainly cereals, from Kambuga and Nyarutojo, for a period of 10 years. She sells to the local community and she is able to generate 100,000 weekly. She also has a restaurant from which she gets an additional income. 

To start the produce selling business, Mary used her own harvests and she has expanded the business over time. She is very hard working and her dream is to educate her children to higher levels and to expand her produce business. The loans have improved Mary's working capital and she needs a loan to be able to buy more cereals for sale.

loans.name: Sidra Sehar

texts.en:
Sidra Sehar is a very supportive lady who provides full financial support to her husband by doing embroidery work. She receives orders from her community clients and fills them on time to earn profit. She is also a very good housewife and fulfills her responsibilities very well. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further improvement of her embroidery business. She will utilize the loan in buying embroidery material such as beads, colored thread and cloth in bulk that will allow her to complete the orders on time and earn better profits. 

She has been doing this business for the past seven years and is hopeful that this loan investment will be a profitable one for her business and she will be able to provide better living facilities to her family as a result. She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 

She comes from Kasur which is a small city of Punjab, Pakistan, known for its tannery industry. Her home is situated in Azher colony and contains 2 rooms. She has been living there with her family for many years.

loans.use: To buy embroidery material for embroidery business.

loans.name: George

He has been in the business for seven years and has employed one person to assist him. He has gained a lot of business management skills through the trainings conducted by Faulu Kenya.  He hopes to expand his business within five years. He needs 20,000 KES to buy auto spare parts.

loans.name: Ma. Corazon

Corazon is requesting a loan for 10,000 PHP through NWTF, which she will use to purchase more stock to sell.  Ma. Corazon has been in this business for three years. She also earns additional income from room rentals.  In the future, Ma. Corazon would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Sabah

texts.en:
Sabah is a 49-year-old widow. She has four children under the age of 18. After her husband passed away, she searched for something to do to be able to support her children, so she decided to start selling cleaning products at her house. 

Her business basically is buying a large quantity of cleaning products and refilling it in small packing bottles for resale. Now Sabah has applied for this loan to buy other kinds of cleaning products and sell them to increase her income so she will be able to support her family.

loans.use: To buy other kinds of cleaning products for resale.

loans.name: Wycliffe Keya

texts.en:
28-year-old Wycliffe Keya A. is from Mahanga.  He is married to Caroline, and they have two children who are both in school.

Wycliffe has a livestock business that he has been running for the past 10 years.  He is applying for his first loan from KADET LTD after being introduced to it by a friend. He intends to use the money to buy more livestock worth KES 20,000. The profits will be used to provide for the family's needs and invested back into the business.  His dream is to see his business grow and diversify into farming in the future.

loans.use: to buy more livestock to add to his stock.

loans.name: Caro

texts.en:
Caro is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.
	
For the past three years, Caro has operated a cosmetic shop and a beauty salon business. Her customers are neighbors and passers-by. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of establishing another beauty salon in the future. 

Caro decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.  With her KES 20,000 loan she wants to purchase hair food oil, relaxer and hair treatments.

loans.use: to purchase hair food oil, relaxer and hair treatments.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
As a married parent of seven children, Josephine works hard to support her family.  She has a tricycle transport business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from ready-to-wear clothing.  Josephine is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to renew tools and equipment for her tricycle transport business.

Josephine has been sustaining her business activities through her past 5 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her achieve her dream of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to renew tools and equipment for her tricycle transport business.

loans.name: Janet Kamonya

texts.en:
Janet Kamonya is 52 years old and from the Boyani area in Vihiga. She is a widow with three children who are in college.

Janet has a canteen business that she has been running for the past two years. She is applying for her first loan from KADET Ltd. to enable her to buy more canteen stock like sodas and cooking ingredients. Janet will use the profits made to pay college fees for her children and cater for family needs.

She hopes to see her business grow with time.

loans.use: to buy sodas and cooking ingredients

loans.name: Razel

texts.en:
Razel is married with 3 children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Razel is 30 years old and has a child who is in school.

Razel has a vegetable vending business in the Philippines. Razel requested a 10,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy more stocks of vegetables to sell in her stall.

Razel has been in this business for 4 years.  In the future, Razel would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.name: Salam

texts.en:
Salam is a 20-year-old ambitious young lady. Her father Mohammad has retired from the Ministry of Education, and he opened a mini-market at his house 10 years ago. He was able to expand it to be an independent store outside the house.

Despite Salam’s young age, she was able to find a full-time job to support her family and help her father in their mini-market. Working at the mini-market and taking the customers’ feedback showed her that to be able to expand their business they need to add more variety to the products they sell, so she decided to take a loan to add more products with better quality, of course based on their customers’ needs.

Salam preferred that her father Mohammad appear in the picture instead of her.

loans.use: To buy more products for their mini market.

loans.name: Ruth

Ruth K. is 41 years old and from Galenga villege in Vihiga. She is a widow and a mother of three children.

Ruth has a business of selling rope and has been in it for the past 13 years. She is applying for her first loan from KADET Ltd. after being introduced by a friend. Ruth wants to use the money to buy more rope to add to her stock. 

She hopes to establish her business which will, in turn, improve her living standards.

loans.use: to buy more rope to add to her stock.

loans.name: Zahira

texts.en:
Zahira is a 39-year-old mother, married to Abd Al Hamid, a taxi driver. She has two young sons.

Zahira started her home-business a year ago selling cosmetics and Dead Sea products at her house to help her husband with the family income. 

 Now she has applied for a loan to vary the products she sells, by adding other kinds of cosmetics and other brands.

loans.name: Liza

To make a living, Liza owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Liza has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 12,250 PHP a month. Liza is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and pay for the labor cost of farm maintenance. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Liza from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Now Nawal has applied for this loan to expand their store and to add more variety to the products they sell. Since Nawal is a conservative person, she recommended that her husband Ahmad appear in the picture instead of her.

loans.name: Zorigt

texts.en:
Mr. Zorigt is 58 years old and lives with his wife, son, daughter and son-in-law in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Zorigt owns a plot of land and small house on it and the family live there all packed together. Zorigt’s wife is retired and Zorigt works at Ulaanbaatar city’s Musical College as a plumber. 

Next year, Zorigt is planning to build a house in his neighborhood for his son, who works at a supermarket retail chain as a delivery truck driver. The house where Mr. Zorigt’s family live was built in 1987 and it really needs some renovations now. The loan Mr. Zorigt is taking will be used to buy necessary building materials such as a cement, sand, plaster, gypsum boards, paints, wood, wallpapers and to do interior renovations to his family house.

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma Y. is 51 years old and married with four adult-aged children. Elma is a hog-raiser working in the Philippines who earns approximately PHP 4,000 per month. 

Elma is asking for a loan of PHP 8,000 to purchase livestock feed and vitamins. Elma and has been raising hogs for almost 10 years.

In the future, Elma hopes to improve her hog-raising business as a source of their daily living. She also believes that with patience and strong determination, she can reach her business goals.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins

location.town: Mabasa, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Bilqees

texts.en:
Bilqees lives in a small city called Kasur. It is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and is famous for its leather industry. Her house is located in the area of Azher colony. Bilqees is a very supportive lady who operates an embroidery business to support her family financially. She also fulfills her responsibilities as a housewife and a mother very well.  Her husband’s name is M. A. and he is a property dealer. He helps people find homes for rent and for sale. His business is going well and he earns reasonable profits from it. 

Bilqees has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her son who is also involved in an embroidery business and needs a loan to buy embroidery material such as beads, colored thread and clothes in bulk to fulfill orders on time. He learned this art from Bilqees and has six years of experience in this field. Bilqees hopes that a loan will have a positive impact on his business and will increase his profits. 

She is a new loan user and this is her first loan application to Asasah. She is hopeful that it will be a profitable experience for her family.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda B. is 56 years old and married with seven adult-aged children. Erlinda earns about PHP 4,000 when she sells one of her raised hogs. 

Erlinda has been raising hogs for 25 years. Erlinda is asking for a loan of 6,000 PHP to purchase additional breeding hogs and feed.

In the future, Erlinda hopes to strengthen the kind of business she manages to make it more profitable in order to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase additional hogs and feed

location.town: Mabasa, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Florencia

texts.en:
Florencia C. is from the village of Bagong, Maslob, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 63 years old. Florencia is married and has five adult children. 

To make a living, Florencia sells food and drinks for passenger in the bus terminal. Florencia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Florencia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Florencia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fruits, candies, cookies and bottled water for sale. This will be the first loan taken out by Florencia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches  covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fruits, candies, cookies and bottled water for sale.

loans.name: Jelida

texts.en:
Jelida K. is 74 years old from the Gamalenga area in Vihiga. She is a widow and supports three grandchildren who are still in school.

Jelida has a tailoring business that she has been doing for the past 41 years. She has established a number of clients through the years. She is applying for her first loan from KADET Ltd. to enable her to buy more tailoring materials.

She hopes to be able to cater to the needs of her grandchildren and see them through school.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials.

loans.name: Kurbonmuhammad

texts.en:
Kurbonmuhammad B. is a 47-year-old cattleman who is married and has seven children. 

He purchases the cattle in the local market and then he breeds and sells them. The cattle are kept in the house and it takes a lot of effort to care for them. Every day, Kurbonmuhammad gets up early in the morning in order to feed his animals. And all day, until late at night, he is busy looking after the cattle. 

Kurbonmuhammad would like to purchase more cattle to expand his business. For this purpose he requested a loan.  
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes having been a key post along the Silk Road and having witnessed the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to epic mountain passes, a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC, and communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty.

IMON's History:
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy cattle and to expand the business.

loans.name: Celina

texts.pt:
Celina nasceu  na provincia de Gaza tem 46 anos de idade e divorciada mãe de 5 filhos de  11 aos 27 anos, Duas é que vão a escola. Responsabiliza se pelos seus 3 netos que vivem com ela em sua casa consegue poupar por mês 1.000.00mt porque conta com ajuda dos seus filhos.


Celina muda se para o distrito de Namaacha quando seu marido é transferido, é abandonada pelo marido deixando a com 5 filhos por criar, então ela vende seus utencilios domesticos nomeadamente (mantas, capulanas e loiça) e dá início do seu próprio negócio de venda de potes. Pois alguns filhos ja nem podiam ir a escola, hoje é uma grande negociante de potes tem vendido duas veses por semana (quartas e sábados) no Mercado Informal das 5h as 17h assim como também tem tido encomendas na Suazilândia de 15 em 15 dias fazendo a entraga nos meados do mês e o lavantamento do valor no fim de cada mês, assim sucessivamente. Tem gastado 15.000.00mt por viagem tendo de lucro de 8.000.00mt dependendo muito mas da estação do tempo porque o reino suazi aprecia muito este tipo de panelas de alumínio.


Este é o quarto empréstimo na Hluvuku e terceiro com Kiva. Os primeiros 3 emprestimos de (10.000.00, 10.000.00 e de 13.000.00) forao usados para a compra de potes. E este ultimo de 15.000.00mt sera para a mesma finalidade. Esta confiante que ira pagar antes do tempo presvisto e pedir um outro para pintura da sua casa.
texts.en:
Celina was born in the Gaza province.  She is 46 years old and the divorced mother of 5 children ages 11 to 27.  Two of them attend school.  She also supports her 3 grandchildren who live with her.  She is able to save 1.000.00mt per month because she has help from her children.

Celina moved to the Namaacha district when her husband was transferred.  Her husband left herand she had 5 children to raise, so she began selling her housewares door to door (comforters, fabrics, ceramic tableware) and began her own business selling water basins.  Some of her children were not able to go to school.  Today she has a substantial business selling water basins.  She sells twice per week (Thursdays and Saturdays) in the Informal Market from 5 am to 5pm, and she also has orders in Swaziland every 2 weeks.  She delivers around mid month and is paid at the end of every month.  She spends 15.000.00mt per trip and makes a profit of 8.000.00mt depending a great deal on the season. This type of aluminum pots are highly valued in the Swazi kingdom. 

This is Celina's fourth loan with Hluvuku and her third with Kiva.  The first 3 loans (for 10.000.00, 10.000.00 and 13.000.00mt) were used to purchase water basins.  This loan of 15.000.00 will be used for the same purpose.  She is confident that she will pay off the loan before it is due and request another to paint her home.

loans.use: to purchase products (aluminum pots, basins, etc.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase sacks of potatoes and cartons of tomatoes for resale.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora L. is from the village of Balide, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 47 years old. Leonora is widowed and has five adult children. 

To make a living, Leonora sells food and drinks for passengers in the bus terminal. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Leonora joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Leonora is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to  purchase additional biscuits and candies for sale. This will be the first loan taken out by Leonora from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional biscuits and candies for sale.

loans.name: Salvador

texts.en:
Salvador is 59 years of age and married with five adult-aged children. He earns about PHP 100,000 per cropping as a farmer working in the Philippines. 

He has been growing corn for 40 years. Salvador is asking for a loan of 25,000 PHP to buy fertilizers and seeds for his 2.0-hectare fields. He will also use the loan to pay for preparing the land on his farm. He dreams that someday his business will become more profitable to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds and to pay for preparing the land

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia D. is from the village of Lubid, Aurora Zamboanga del Sur. She is 55 years old, widowed and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Virginia sells food and drinks to passengers in the town bus terminal. She has had her business for over three years and earns about 2,800 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2011, Virginia joined Kiva field partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services with the hopes of improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia is requesting her first loan of 5,000 PHP, which she plans to use to purchase ingredients to make cookies and cakes to sell at her stand.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients to make cookies and cakes

loans.name: Esher

texts.en:
Esther A. is a 53-year-old widow who supports two children and one grandchild.  She is from the Gamalenga area in Vihiga.

Esther is applying for her first loan from Kiva field partner Kadet Ltd after being introduced to Kadet by a friend who is already a client.  Esther intends to use her loan money to buy more cowpea seeds to plant, and she will use any additional profits she makes at harvest time to pay for her dependents' school fees.

loans.use: to buy cowpea seeds to plant

loans.name: Nonita

texts.en:
Nonita L. is from the village of Alang-alang Aurora Zamboanga del Sur. She is 62 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she sells food and drinks to passengers at the local bus terminal. Nonita has had her business for over four years and earns about 2,400 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2011, Nonita joined Kiva field partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services with the hopes of improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nonita is requesting her first loan of 5,000 PHP which she plans to use to purchase raw ingredients to make snacks to sell at her stall.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients to make snacks

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice K. is 43-year-old widow who supports two children. She is from the Gamalenya area and has a poultry business that she has been running for the past year.

Beatrice is applying for her first loan from Kiva field partner Kadet Ltd to enable her buy more chickens. Beatrice will use any additional profits made from her business to support her children.  In future, Beatrice hopes to see her business grow and wants to be able to take good care of her dependents.

loans.use: to buy more chickens

loans.name: Armando Leornardo

texts.pt:
Armando leonardo nasceu em Maputo tem 45 anos de idade, é casado pai de 3 filhos com idades compriendidas entre os 16 aos 18 anos todos vão a escola. Responsabiliza se pelo seu pai que vive em Inhambane enviando lhe uma cesta básica no valor de 1000.00mt em cada 3 meses.

Leonardo sai de Inhambane para o distrito de Namaacha no tempo da guerra  aprocura de emprego,durante 12 anos  trabalha como empregado doméstico, opta em dar inicio do seu próprio negócio de venda de recargas Mcel/VODAcom e cambio de divisas. pois tem muita aderência porque vende na zona fronteiriça e mesmo assim nao consegue satisfazer a demanda dos clientes, trabalha das 7h as 20horas horario em que feicham a fornteira e conta com ajuda de dois empregados.
